segment.source: You can encourage your customers to leave feedback by launching Feedback Hub from your app.
segment.target: You can encourage your customers to leave feedback by launching Feedback Hub from your app.

segment.source: Launch Feedback Hub from your app
segment.target: Launch Feedback Hub from your app

segment.source: Launch Feedback Hub from your app
segment.target: Launch Feedback Hub from your app

segment.source: You can encourage your customers to leave feedback by adding a control (such as a button) to your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app that launches Feedback Hub.
segment.target: You can encourage your customers to leave feedback by adding a control (such as a button) to your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app that launches Feedback Hub.

segment.source: Feedback Hub is a preinstalled app that provides a single place to gather feedback on Windows and installed apps.
segment.target: Feedback Hub is a preinstalled app that provides a single place to gather feedback on Windows and installed apps.

segment.source: All customer feedback that is submitted for your app through Feedback Hub is collected and presented to you in the Feedback report in the Windows Dev Center dashboard, so you can see the problems, suggestions, and upvotes that your customers have submitted in one report.
segment.target: All customer feedback that is submitted for your app through Feedback Hub is collected and presented to you in the Feedback report in the Windows Dev Center dashboard, so you can see the problems, suggestions, and upvotes that your customers have submitted in one report.

segment.source: Note The Feedback report is currently available only to developer accounts that have joined the Dev Center Insider Program.
segment.target: Note The Feedback report is currently available only to developer accounts that have joined the Dev Center Insider Program.

segment.source: To launch Feedback Hub from your app, use an API that is provided by the Microsoft Store Engagement and Monetization SDK.
segment.target: To launch Feedback Hub from your app, use an API that is provided by the Microsoft Store Engagement and Monetization SDK.

segment.source: We recommend that you use this API to launch Feedback Hub from a UI element in your app that follows our design guidelines.
segment.target: We recommend that you use this API to launch Feedback Hub from a UI element in your app that follows our design guidelines.

segment.source: Note Feedback Hub is available only on devices that are running Windows 10 version 10.0.14271 or later.
segment.target: Note Feedback Hub is available only on devices that are running Windows 10 version 10.0.14271 or later.

segment.source: We recommend that you show a feedback control in your app only if the Feedback Hub is available on the user's device.
segment.target: We recommend that you show a feedback control in your app only if the Feedback Hub is available on the user's device.

segment.source: The code in this topic demonstrates how to do this.
segment.target: The code in this topic demonstrates how to do this.

segment.source: How to launch Feedback Hub from your app
segment.target: How to launch Feedback Hub from your app

segment.source: To launch Feedback Hub from your app:
segment.target: To launch Feedback Hub from your app:

segment.source: Install the Microsoft Store Engagement and Monetization SDK.
segment.target: Install the Microsoft Store Engagement and Monetization SDK.

segment.source: In addition to the API for launching Feedback Hub, this SDK also provides APIs for other features such as running experiments in your apps with A/B testing and displaying ads.
segment.target: In addition to the API for launching Feedback Hub, this SDK also provides APIs for other features such as running experiments in your apps with A/B testing and displaying ads.

segment.source: For more information about this SDK, see Monetize your app and engage customers with the Store Engagement and Monetization SDK.
segment.target: For more information about this SDK, see Monetize your app and engage customers with the Store Engagement and Monetization SDK.

segment.source: Open your project in Visual Studio.
segment.target: Open your project in Visual Studio.

segment.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the References node for your project and click Add Reference.
segment.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the References node for your project and click Add Reference.

segment.source: In Reference Manager, expand Universal Windows and click Extensions.
segment.target: In Reference Manager, expand Universal Windows and click Extensions.

segment.source: In the list of SDKs, click the check box next to Microsoft Store Engagement SDK and click OK.
segment.target: In the list of SDKs, click the check box next to Microsoft Store Engagement SDK and click OK.

segment.source: In your project, add the control that you want to show to users to launch Feedback Hub, such as a button.
segment.target: In your project, add the control that you want to show to users to launch Feedback Hub, such as a button.

segment.source: We recommend that you configure the control as follows:
segment.target: We recommend that you configure the control as follows:

segment.source: Set the font of the content shown in the control to Segoe MDL2 Assets.
segment.target: Set the font of the content shown in the control to Segoe MDL2 Assets.

segment.source: Set the text in the control to the hexadecimal Unicode character code E939.
segment.target: Set the text in the control to the hexadecimal Unicode character code E939.

segment.source: This is the character code for the recommended feedback icon in the Segoe MDL2 Assets font.
segment.target: This is the character code for the recommended feedback icon in the Segoe MDL2 Assets font.

segment.source: Set the visibility of the control to hidden.
segment.target: Set the visibility of the control to hidden.

segment.source: Note Feedback Hub is available only on devices that are running Windows 10 version 10.0.14271 or later.
segment.target: Note Feedback Hub is available only on devices that are running Windows 10 version 10.0.14271 or later.

segment.source: We recommend that you hide your feedback control by default and show it in your initialization code only if the Feedback Hub is available on the user's device.
segment.target: We recommend that you hide your feedback control by default and show it in your initialization code only if the Feedback Hub is available on the user's device.

segment.source: The next step demonstrates how to do this.
segment.target: The next step demonstrates how to do this.

segment.source: The following code demonstrates the XAML definition of a Button that is configured as described above.
segment.target: The following code demonstrates the XAML definition of a Button that is configured as described above.

segment.source: In your initialization code for the app page that hosts your feedback control, use the IsSupported property of the Feedback class to determine whether the Feedback Hub is available on the user's device.
segment.target: In your initialization code for the app page that hosts your feedback control, use the IsSupported property of the Feedback class to determine whether the Feedback Hub is available on the user's device.

segment.source: If this property returns true, make the control visible.
segment.target: If this property returns true, make the control visible.

segment.source: The following code demonstrates how to do this for a Button.
segment.target: The following code demonstrates how to do this for a Button.

segment.source: In the event handler that runs when the user clicks the control, call the static LaunchFeedbackAsync method of the Feedback class to launch the Feedback Hub app.
segment.target: In the event handler that runs when the user clicks the control, call the static LaunchFeedbackAsync method of the Feedback class to launch the Feedback Hub app.

segment.source: There are two overloads for this method: one without parameters, and another one that accepts a dictionary of key and value pairs that contain metadata that you want to associate with the feedback.
segment.target: There are two overloads for this method: one without parameters, and another one that accepts a dictionary of key and value pairs that contain metadata that you want to associate with the feedback.

segment.source: The following example demonstrates how to launch Feedback Hub in the Click event handler for a Button.
segment.target: The following example demonstrates how to launch Feedback Hub in the Click event handler for a Button.

segment.source: Design recommendations for your feedback UI
segment.target: Design recommendations for your feedback UI

segment.source: To launch Feedback Hub, we recommend that you add a UI element in your app (such as a button) that displays the following standard feedback icon from the Segoe MDL2 Assets font and the character code E939.
segment.target: To launch Feedback Hub, we recommend that you add a UI element in your app (such as a button) that displays the following standard feedback icon from the Segoe MDL2 Assets font and the character code E939.

segment.source: ![]Feedback icon](images/feedback_icon.PNG)
segment.target: ![]Feedback icon](images/feedback_icon.PNG)

segment.source: We also recommend that you use one or more of the following placement options for linking to Feedback Hub in your app.
segment.target: We also recommend that you use one or more of the following placement options for linking to Feedback Hub in your app.

segment.source: Directly in the app bar.
segment.target: Directly in the app bar.

segment.source: Depending on your implementation, you may wish to use the icon only or add text (as shown below).
segment.target: Depending on your implementation, you may wish to use the icon only or add text (as shown below).

segment.source: ![]Feedback icon](images/feedback_appbar_placement.png)
segment.target: ![]Feedback icon](images/feedback_appbar_placement.png)

segment.source: In your app's settings.
segment.target: In your app's settings.

segment.source: This is a more subtle way to provide access to Feedback Hub.
segment.target: This is a more subtle way to provide access to Feedback Hub.

segment.source: In the example below, the Feedback link appears as one of the links under App.
segment.target: In the example below, the Feedback link appears as one of the links under App.

segment.source: ![]Feedback icon](images/feedback_settings_placement.png)
segment.target: ![]Feedback icon](images/feedback_settings_placement.png)

segment.source: In an event-driven flyout.
segment.target: In an event-driven flyout.

segment.source: This is useful when you want to query your customers about a specific question before launching into the Windows Feedback Hub.
segment.target: This is useful when you want to query your customers about a specific question before launching into the Windows Feedback Hub.

segment.source: For example, after your app uses a certain feature, you might prompt the customer with a specific question about their satisfaction with that feature.
segment.target: For example, after your app uses a certain feature, you might prompt the customer with a specific question about their satisfaction with that feature.

segment.source: If the customer chooses to respond, your app launches Feedback Hub.
segment.target: If the customer chooses to respond, your app launches Feedback Hub.
